newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria bans multiple taxes by government agencies.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria bans multiple taxes by government agencies.

text.p: Nigeria's federal government on Tuesday published a list of taxes approved for the three tiers of government in the African country and banned the practice of charging the same tax by different agencies.

"With the publication of the list of taxes and levies collectible by each tier of government, all forms of multiple taxes and levies in the country are abolished," the ministry of finance said in a statement in the capital Abuja.
"No levy or tax should be imposed concurrently by more than one tier of government in any state," said the statement, signed by finance minister Anthony Ani.
Taxes approved at federal level include company and petroleum profits taxes, VAT and personal income taxes for armed forces personnel and residents of Abuja federal territory.

State governments can charge personal income taxes, property, business registration while local governments, the lowest tier of authority are entitled to charge a series of small taxes ranging from marriage to vehicle and radio licence.
Streamlining taxation was a key issue promised by the military government in this year's fiscal budget in January in response to state authorities sealing up businesses in a bid to collect taxes.
"The machinery of tax collection does not involve the closure of any business premises, therefore such practice should be discontinued forthwith," Ani's statement said.
It also barred state and local governments from mounting road blocks to collect taxes and said the police had been given approval to arrest officials setting up such road blocks.
